docs.lead_paragraph: Reports that federal investigators are looking into allegations of accounting irregularities at Global Crossing, another high flier gone bankrupt, should only worsen Wall Street's case of Enronitis. Investors who spent much of the late 1990's buying stocks on faith, often of companies whose financial statements were indecipherable even to sophisticated analysts, are suddenly wary, and with good reason, of accounting gimmicks. Companies unable to explain the math behind their polished bottom-line numbers are seeing their stocks punished in the wake of Enron's collapse. It is a painful yet healthy process, not unlike the breaking of a fever. Accounting standards have become so subjective in recent years, and auditing firms so obsequious to those they are charged with policing, that there is plenty of room for legal mischief. Companies have far too much leeway in playing with numbers so as to issue Wall Street-pleasing quarterly earnings reports that often bear little relation to reality. What constitutes revenue and when it can be recorded are astonishingly open questions. The same can be said about debt, and how companies must account for mergers. The fact that employee stock options need not be counted as an expense is another oft-cited accounting rule that served to warp reality in the late-90's frenzy.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the time, 18 months ago, the idea seemed unthinkable: Enron, the highflying energy company, in bankruptcy. But Citigroup wanted to hedge its bets. The bank, a major lender to Enron, decided to protect itself in the unlikely event that its borrower faltered. Now it is looking smart while others are smarting.
docs.abstract: Citigroup, major lender to Enron Corp, decided 18 months ago to protect itself in unlikely event that its borrower faltered; Citigroup created securities that functioned like insurance policy; if Enron stayed healthy, buyers of securities would receive steady return; but if Enron ran into trouble, Citigroup would stop paying return, keep investors' principal and instead give them Enron debt; now those investors are left to fight for repayment in bankruptcy proceedings; securities, totaling $1.4 billion, were issued from August 2000 to May 2001; securities appear to cover Citigroup's potential losses from Enron; Citigroup has put its Enron loan exposure at $1.2 billion; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An internal lawyer at Arthur Andersen gave employees who worked on its Enron account permission on Oct. 12 to destroy thousands of documents and records having to do with that work, according to investigators for the House Energy and Commerce Committee, one of several Congressional panels investigating Enron's collapse. The permission, which came on a Friday, was followed on Tuesday by Enron's stunning disclosure of a $1.2 billion write-down of its net worth, much of it related to deals Enron had made with partnerships involving its then-chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow. Those partnerships are now central to investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Justice Department and Congressional committees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation announced yesterday that UBS Warburg had won the bidding for its energy-trading business, which was the crown jewel of Enron and was responsible for about 90 percent of its revenue. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed in the company's presentation to a federal bankruptcy judge yesterday afternoon, barely an hour after the end of nearly 24 hours of marathon negotiations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lenders, partners, customers and governments in some 40 countries struggled today to determine what might become of the Enron Corporation's far-flung empire of overseas operations and investments, most of them in the energy sector. Enron, which is based in Houston, derived almost one-quarter of its revenue from outside the United States. The confusion was especially great in Brazil, where Enron has been among the most aggressive investors in a newly privatized energy industry. Among Enron's 20-odd ventures here are stakes in gas distributors, power plants, natural gas pipelines and one of the country's largest electric utilities.
docs.abstract: Lenders, partners, customers and governments in some 40 nations struggle to determine fate of Enron Corp's far-flung empire of overseas operations and investments; confusion is especially great in Brazil, where Enron was aggressive investor; Enron Europe files for court protection from creditors and is place under control of administrator, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which is moving rapidly to sell Enron unit; exchanges in Britain and Scandinavia bar Enron from trading and clearing; map and table of Enron assets (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the Enron Corporation used its political muscle to build the markets in which it thrived, pushing relentlessly on Capitol Hill and in bureaucratic backwaters to deregulate the nation's natural gas and electricity businesses. Its achievement, as one Enron executive said today, in creating a ''regulatory black hole'' fit nicely with what he called the company's ''core management philosophy, which was to be the first mover into a market and to make money in the initial chaos and lack of transparency.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge granted a 90-day delay today in the case of the former chief financial officer for the Enron Corporation, Andrew S. Fastow, because of the huge amount of paperwork that has been generated. Mr. Fastow was not present when the judge, Kenneth Hoyt of United States District Court, granted the delay in the case, which has not yet been scheduled for trial. The additional time was granted to permit lawyers to better manage the documentation.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge Kenneth Hoyt grants 90-day delay in case of former Enron chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow because of huge amount of paperwork that has been generated; Fastow was indicted on Oct 31 on 78 counts of fraud, money laundering, conspiracy, obstruction of justice and other charges related to Enron's fall in 2001 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: J. P. Morgan Chase announced yesterday that it would receive about $580 million from insurance companies as part of a settlement resolving one of the most contentious disputes touched off by Enron's collapse. The settlement is a partial victory for J. P. Morgan, which had sought nearly $1 billion from the insurers and will take a charge of about $400 million to cover the difference.
docs.abstract: J P Morgan Chase will get about $580 million from insurance companies as part of settlement of claims stemming from Enron collapse; will take charge of about $400 million to cover difference between settlement and nearly $1 billion that had been sought in lawsuit; bank will also create $900-million reserve to cover anticipated legal settlements; will post quarterly loss as result; insurance dispute centers on charge that J P Morgan defrauded insurers, disguising loans to Enron as commodities trades; insurers had issued bonds guaranteeing trades, and bank sought to collect on them after Enron filed for bankruptcy in Dec 2001; settlement explained (M)
